title: The Burnt Offering
shortSummary: Leviticus chapter 1 details God's instructions to Moses regarding the burnt offering, a key sacrificial practice for the Israelites. This chapter emphasizes the importance of offering unblemished animals voluntarily to atone for sin and maintain fellowship with God. It reveals God's desire for holiness, obedience, and a sweet-smelling sacrifice symbolizing complete dedication.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Wilderness Journey after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader and prophet who receives God's commands and instructs the Israelites on proper worship.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: The high priest whose sons serve as priests responsible for handling the sacrifices at the tabernacle.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron's Sons
keyCharacters.description: The priests who perform the ritual duties of sprinkling blood, arranging the sacrifice, and burning the offering.

definitions.definition: A voluntary sacrifice wholly consumed by fire on the altar, symbolizing complete surrender and atonement.
An animal that is perfect and free from defects, signifying purity and worthiness for sacrifice.
The act of making reconciliation for sin, restoring the relationship between God and man.
A pleasing aroma to God, representing acceptance of the offering and the worshipper's devotion.

outline.heading: Godâ€™s Command to Moses
outline.description: God calls Moses from the tabernacle and instructs him to tell Israel how to bring offerings to the LORD, establishing the foundation for the sacrificial system.

outline.heading: Burnt Offering of the Cattle
outline.description: Instructions for offering a male without blemish from the herd, including laying on of hands, slaughter, blood sprinkling, and burning, highlighting the necessity of purity and atonement.

outline.heading: Burnt Offering of the Flock
outline.description: Similar regulations for sheep or goats, emphasizing consistency in the sacrificial process and the importance of ritual cleanliness.

outline.heading: Burnt Offering of Birds
outline.description: Provision for those who cannot afford larger animals, showing God's accessibility and the inclusiveness of worship through turtledoves or young pigeons.

application: Offer your life wholly and without blemish to God as a living sacrifice, reflecting sincere devotion and obedience.
Approach God with reverence and humility, recognizing the need for atonement and cleansing from sin.
Serve faithfully in the roles God has assigned, just as the priests performed their duties with care and obedience.
Trust in God's provision for worship, knowing He accepts offerings from all who come with a sincere heart.

keyVerses.text: And he shall put his hand upon the head of the burnt offering; and it shall be accepted for him to make atonement for him.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the symbolic transfer of sin and the necessity of atonement for reconciliation with God.

keyVerses.text: But his inwards and his legs shall he wash in water: and the priest shall burn all on the altar, to be a burnt sacrifice, an offering made by fire, of a sweet savour unto the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: It underscores the importance of ritual purity and the offering being a pleasing aroma to God, symbolizing acceptance.

keyVerses.text: And he shall cleave it with the wings thereof, but shall not divide it asunder: and the priest shall burn it upon the altar, upon the wood that is upon the fire: it is a burnt sacrifice, an offering made by fire, of a sweet savour unto the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: This verse concludes the chapter by affirming the completeness and dedication required in the burnt offering.
